questions.text: After 11 days in the intensive care unit following an automobile accident, an 18-year-old woman develops increased urinary urgency, burning during urination, and lower abdominal pain. When her urine is cultured, a typical pigment is observed in the Petri dish as shown in the image. What is the most likely organism causing these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Serratia is a common cause of nosocomial urinary tract infections, along with E. coli, Proteus, Klebsiella and Pseudomonas. 
Some strains produce a non diffusible red pigment - Prodigiosin. 
Nosocomial infections generally are more resistant than community acquired infect ions. 
Serratia is a gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic bacillus. Motile in nature.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician complaining of a fever and a sore throat for 2 days. Physical examination reveals the presence of purulent tonsillar exudates and swollen, tender anterior cervical nodes. Culture of the tonsillar exudate reveals gram-positive cocci. Which of the following are characteristic of the organism most likely causing this boy's infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This patient presents with the classic symptoms (fever, sore throat, anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, lack of cough) for streptococcal pharyngitis (strep throat) . 

This is caused by the catalase-negative, β - hemolytic, bacitracin-sensitive Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS). 
Bacitracin sensitive and PYR test positive.
Diagnosis is confirmed with a rapid strep test or with throat swab culture, and treatment is with penicillin.

questions.text: A 32-year-old NRI man presents to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and palpitations. He and his family recently immigrated from Peru. X-ray of the chest demonstrates pulmonary congestion. Echocardiography reveals biventricular dilatation with massive cardiac enlargement. Endomyocardial biopsy demonstrates the presence of intracellular protozoan parasites as shown in the image. Which vector is most likely responsible for transmitting this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The patient has myocarditis due to Trypanosoma cruzi.

This infection, known as Chagas disease, is endemic in vast areas of South America and is transmitted by Triatoma (reduviid) bugs, also known as "kissingbugs." 
Resevoirs of the T. cruzi include wild animals such as rodents, raccoons, dogs, and humans. 
T. cruzi is an intracellular protozoan that localizes mainly in the heart and nerve cells of the myenteric plexus, leading to myocarditis and dysmotility of hollow organs such the esophagus, colon, and ureter. 
Cardiac involvement manifests with ventricular dilatation and congestive heart failure secondary to myocyte necrosis and fibrosis. 
Intracellular parasites can be visualized in tissue sections, as shown in the image
Chagas disease is also a cause of acquired achalasia. This is due to loss of innervation to the lower esophageal sphincter, which prevents relaxation of the sphincter. This, in turn, leads to dilation of the distal third of the esophagus as food is unable to enter the stomach. A similar pathologic mechanism accounts for megacolon and megaureter in Chagas disease.

choices.text: It is a non-enveloped RNA virus with a double-stranded, segmented genome
It is a prokaryotic organism lacking a cell wall
It is an enveloped RNA virus with a single-stranded, non-segmented genome
It is an enveloped RNA virus with a single-stranded, segmented genome

questions.text: A previously healthy 6-mont h-old girl is brought to the pediatrician with a cough that has been increasing in severity for several days. Her parents worry that she is having occasional difficulty breathing. On examination, temperature is 37.4°C and oxygen saturation is 92%. Auscultation of the lungs reveals inspiratory crackles and expiratory wheezing. The pediatrician suspects the child is suffering from bronchiolitis, and this diagnosis is confirmed through serologic analysis of a nasopharyngeal swab. Which of the following describes the etiologic agent of the girl's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The most common cause of bronchiolitis and pneumonia in children is respiratory syncytial virus (RSV). 

This paramyxovirus has a single stranded, non-segmented RNA genome and is surrounded by a lipid envelope. 
Clinically, RSV can present as either an upper respiratory tract or a lower respiratory tract infection. 
When it infects the lower respiratory tract, symptoms may include cough, tachypnea, low-grade fever, and a mildly reduced oxygen saturation.
Crackles and expiratory wheezing can be heard on auscultation. A presumptive clinical diagnosis of RSV can now be verified through a rapidserological test for viral antigens.

questions.text: The world’s first Plasmid DNA based vaccine against SARS CoV2 produced in India is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

DCGI approved ZyCoV-D, the only needle-free COVID vaccine in the world • World’s first Plasmid DNA Vaccine for COVID-19 by EUA.

ZyCoV-D will be administered in three doses. 
Apart from adults, for the first time adolescents in the age group of 12-18 years will take the vaccine shot in India.
Safety, efficacy and immunogenicity of the vaccine is well established.

choices.text: Fever, new murmur, small erythematous lesions on the palms, and splinter haemorrhages on the nail bed
Simultaneous ataxia, urinary incontinence, and cognitive decline

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student comes to the physician with a 12-hour history of a temperature of 39°C. He also complains of headache and neck stiffness. Physical exam reveals nuchal rigidity. A smear of his cerebrospinal fluid reveals gram-negative diplococci, cultures grow on Thayer-Martin media. Medical history is significant for absence of vaccinations as a child. What symptoms can develop as a severe complication of this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The causative agent in this scenario, based on the Gram stain, is Neisseria meningitidis. 

Disseminated infection by this bacterium can result in hypotension, tachycardia, a rapidly enlarging petechial or purpuric rash , disseminated intravascular coagulation, and coma. 
Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome is a possible complication of meningococcemia. In this disorder, bilateral hemorrhage into the adrenal glands causes acute adrenal insufficiency

questions.text: An 18-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of a runny nose, sneezing, and difficulty breathing for the past 2 days. His medical history Is significant for cadaveric kidney transplant 2 years ago, sore throat 2 weeks ago that resolved on its own, and an allergy to latex. He says that when he goes outside or is away from his house, his symptoms improve. On physical examination his turbinates are boggy and violaceous. This type of reaction is most likely which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This patient's symptoms are characteristic of allergic rhinitis, likely due to an Indoor allergen. 

This response is an example of a type I hypersensitivity reaction In which an allergen cross-links antigen-specific IgE on the surface of mast cells and basophils. Anaphylaxis, is a drug or food allergy that occurs via the same mechanism. 
Subsequently the mast cells and basophils release vasoactive amines, such as histamine. Because antibodies are preformed in this type of hypersensitivity, the reaction develops quite rapidly.

choices.text: A heavily encapsulated yeast that is not dimorphic
A mold with septate hyphae that branch at a V-shaped 45-degree angle
A mold with irregular non-septate hyphae branching at wide angles
Cigar-shaped budding yeast visible in pus

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the physician with fever~ malaise, cough, and wheezing. During the physical examination, the patient intermittently coughs up brownish-colored mucus. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. A chest x-ray reveals a mass within a left lung cavity. The pathology report on mucus specimens indicates infection with an identified opportunistic microorganism. Another species in this infectious agent's family can also produce a toxin that can result in hepatocellular carcinoma. What is the microscopic morphology of this agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This patient likely has an infection wit h Aspergillus fumigatus, a ubiquitous fungus that can formaspergillomas ("fungus balls," shown in the image) in patients with preexisting lung cavities. 

Under the microscope, A fumigatus appears as a nondimorphic mold with septate hyphae that branch at V-shaped 45-degree angles. 
In patients with significant hemoptysis, treatment is surgical removal of the aspergilloma.
Otherwise, itraconazole may be given. Aspergillus infection via inhalation can lead to aspergillomas.
Aspergillus flavus is another member of the Aspergillus family that is classically found growing on grains. It produces aflatoxins that, when ingested in sufficient quantities, can cause hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: Choose the appropriate medium from the list used for the cultivation of a fastidious pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Enriched Medium : Medium to meet the nutritional requirements of more exacting bacteria by the addition of substances such as blood, serum or egg to a basal medium. Example : Blood agar, Lofffler’s serum slope.

Enrichment medium : Broth which inhibits the unwanted organisms.
Differential medium : Used to differentiate the characters of a microbe.

questions.text: An 12-year-old boy is taken to his pediatrician because his mother noticed a raised, scaly area on the back of his head. He examines the boy’s scalp with a Wood’s lamp, He does not notice fluorescence. He collects scrapings of the area. No organisms are seen on microscopic examination, but a mold grows on Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA). Numerous microconidia but no macroconidia are seen on microscopic examination as shown in the picture. Which organism is most likely responsible for this patient 's infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This patient has a dermatophyte infection caused by Trichophyton. 

The negative Wood’s light examination is consistent with the characteristics of this organism. The presence of abundant microconidia is also consistent with Trichophyton.
Microsporum infections typically fluoresce under the Wood’s lamp. 
Epidermophyton infections are characterized by abundant macroconidia but not microconidia. 
Malassezia grows as a yeast and not as a mold. 
Trichosporon causes infections of the hair, forming adherent nodules on the hair shaft. Conidia are not observed in culture

choices.text: Increased concentrating ability of the kidney

questions.text: An abdominal CT in a 50-year-old patient with Conn syndrome shows multiple small adrenocortical masses. Which of the following clinical findings are likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hypertension 

The symptoms of Conn syndrome or primary hyperaldosteronism develop from a chronic hypersecretion of aldosterone. Patients are hypertensive with expanded blood volume with a decreased hematocrit. They also have a hypokalemia. Sodium levels may not be markedly elevated because of a renal escape phenomenon.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the doctor for a 6-month check-up following diuretic therapy and recommended dietary changes for his essential hypertension. His bp is 140/95 mm Hg. His serum aldosterone is elevated. Aldosterone secretion is increased due to a decrease in which of the following in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sodium

Dietary modification and diuretic therapy have probably led to decrease in plasma sodium level. Hyponatremia is associated with a decrease in ECF volume which increases Renin secretion and therefore, aldosterone secretion.

questions.text: A patient undergoes cardiac transplantation for severe idiopathic cardiomyopathy. Post-surgery the patient undergoes a cardiac rehabilitation programme in which he is started on a walking regimen. In cardiac transplant patients, increase in stroke volume during exercise occurs mainly by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Decrease in venous capacitance

Transplanted heart does not have sympathetic or parasympathetic nerve supply. It responds to increased catecholamine secretion from the adrenal medulla during exercise. 

Increase in stroke volume can be due to increased preload (EDV), decreased afterload or increased myocardial contractility. Catecholamines will cause a venoconstriction which decreases the venous compliance and increases venous return. Increased venous return increases the EDV or the preload, increasing the initial length of the ventricular muscle fibres which in turn increases the tension generated and the stroke volume (Frank-Starling’s law).

questions.text: Twenty years ago, a 65-year-old man underwent vagotomy for his refractory peptic ulcer disease. As a result, which of the following gastrointestinal motor activities will be affected most?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Orad stomach accommodation

Orad stomach accommodation (also k/a receptive relaxation of stomach) depends exclusively on an intact vago-vagal reflex. Secondary esophageal peristalsis, intestinal segmentation and MMCs are unaffected by vagotomy.

choices.text: Impaired diffusion across the respiratory membrane
Impaired oxygen utilization by the tissues
Impaired oxygen delivery to the tissues

questions.text:
A scientist doing experiments with sodium cyanide started experiencing headache, dizziness, clumsiness, decreased visual acuity, nausea. He was taken to the Emergency. Blood values obtained while he was breathing room air were as follows:
Hb: 16 g/dL
Pao2: 102 mm Hg
Sao2: 97.5%
Paco2: 27 mm Hg
Pvo2: 65 mm Hg
Svo2: 90%
pH: 7.57
[HCO3-]: 23mEq/L
Cardiac output: 5.6L/min
Hypoxia in this patient is likely due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Impaired oxygen utilization by the tissues

Cyanide impairs oxidative phosphorylation which in turn impairs the ability of the tissues to utilize oxygen. The increased arterio-venous oxygen difference in this patient points towards an impired oxygen utilization by the tissues.

•	Niacin (vit. B3 or nicotinic acid) is derived from typtophan (aromatic amino acid) where QPRTase is the rate limiting enzyme. 
•	Leucine (aliphatic) inhibits QPRTase. 
•	Jowar (sorghum vulgare) has excess of leucine, thereby causing pellagra.

questions.text: Which among the following amino acids absorbs UV light?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tyrosine
Ref.: Read the text below
Sol : 
•	Amino acids which absorb 250-290 nm UV light are : phenylalanine, tyrosine, tryptophan (aromatic amino acids) 
Important biochemicals & the wavelength of light which they absorb : 
•	Nucleotides – 260 nm 
•	Aromatic amino acids – 250-290 nm 
•	NADH – 340 nm 
•	Porphyrin – 400 nm (Soret band)

questions.text: The concept of Lac operon was first described by Francois Jacob and Jacques Monod in E.coli. CAP in Lac operon is an example of :
questions.solution:
Correct Answr (A)

Positive regulator
Ref.: Read the text below
Sol : 
Operon 
•	A set of adjacent genes whose mRNA is synthesized in one piece, plus the adjacent regulatory signals that affect transcription of the genes. 
There are two types of operons 
•	Inducible operon : Substrate should be present before transcription of genes involved in its breakdown occurs.E.g. Lac Operon 
•	Repressible Operon : Transcription occurs continuously and the repressor protein must be activated to stop transcription E.g Trp (tryptophan) Operon

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency can result in Homocystinuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Vit B12
Ref.: Read the text below
Sol : 
HOMOCYSTINURIA 
Classic Homocystinuria 
•	Due to cystathionine β–synthetase deficiency Clinical features : 
•	MR, skeletal deformities 
•	Ectopia lentis, CAD Screening : Cyanide nitroprusside test Non-classic Homocystinuria 
•	Homocystinuria due to defects in methyl cobalamin formation 
•	Rx: Vit. B12 in the form of hydroxycobalamin 
•	Homocystinuria the to deficiency of methylene tetrahydrofolate reductase 
•	Rx : Folic acid + Vit. B6 + Vit. B12, Betaine and methionine supplementation

questions.text: During replantation of an amputated limb which of the following is done first :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ORDER OF REPAIR

After all structures have been thoroughly cleansed, débrided, and identified, repair is begun. As indicated in the discussion that follows, certain conditions or circumstances dictate a variation in the order of repair. The following is our usual order of repair of damaged structures. Discussions of digit, hand, and arm replantations are included. 

1. Shorten and internally fix bone.

2. Repair extensor tendons.

3. Repair flexor tendons (2 and 3 may be reversed, or flexor tendon repair may be delayed).

4. Repair arteries.

5. Repair nerves.

6. Repair veins.

7. Close or cover wound.

questions.text: A previously healthy 45 years old labourer suddenly develops acute lower back pain with right-leg pain and weakness of dorsiflexion of the right great toe. Which of the following is true:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bowel bladder involvement, increasing neurological  deficit or failure of conservative treatment is an indication for surgery. 
Exercises are contraindicated acute pain and6 weeks of trial is advised before carrying out surgical intervention.

questions.text: All of the following features can be observed after the injury to axillary nerve, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Abduction of Shoulder

Upto 15°

• Supraspinatus muscle

• Suprascapular N (C5 C6) 15° to 90°

• Deltoid muscle

• Axillary nerve (C5 C6) Overhead abduction (>90°)

• Serratus anterior muscle (Nerve supply – Long thoracic nerve or N. of Bells – C5 C6 C7)

• Trapezius muscle (Spinal part of accessory nerve)

Axillary nerve supplies deltoid which is responsible for shoulder abduction of 15° to 90°; so injury to axillary nerve would not affect overhead abduction.

questions.text: An 8 year old boy presents with Right Hip Pain and Limping Gait for last one week. The mothers gives history of recent URTI in last month only. The examination revealed limitation of hip movements only in extremes. Blood counts are almost normal except Raised ESR. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Transient Synovitis is the most common cause of limping child where there is recent history of URTI and almost normal hip movements.
